item.title: Parable of the Sower
item.description: I loved the Earthseed parts of this (God is Change), but the dystopia parts went the way of most dystopias for me, almost too limited in its imagination?

item.title: The Black Tides of Heaven
item.description: Note from my future self: this makes an excellent prequel, I should have started with [[books/the red threads of fortune|book 2]]!

item.title: Seven Surrenders
item.description: There’s no way I can talk comprehensively about this series, so for now I’m just going to keep a running list of different things I notice each time I read them.

item.title: A Seditious Affair
item.description: This was my first KJ Charles, purchased and read—I just looked it up—March 2017. I then read the whole series (out of order, of course), re-read this one in 2018, again in 2019, and somehow reviewed nary a one before 2020.

item.title: The Will to Battle
item.description: Reader, I cried like Mycroft Canner. It’s very much the first half of a whole (third quarter of four?), and it needs [[books/perhaps the stars|the last book]] to be complete, but what a feat it is on its own.

item.title: Perhaps the Stars
item.description: I still haven’t found the words to talk about this one. Maybe next year I will. It should be in the Smithsonian, or win the Nobel prize, or something, as one of humanity’s greatest achievements.

item.title: A Gentleman’s Position
item.description: It’s the favorite recurring KJ Charles theme: sometimes you just need a villain instead of a hero. See [[books/wanted a gentleman|Wanted, A Gentleman]] or [[books/the henchmen of zenda|Henchmen of Zenda]], et.

item.title: The Dispossessed
item.description: Sublime. Carefully constructed, nuanced, warmly empathetic, passionately human, complex. If you want a rose-colored ideologue that purports to fix problems with simplistic utopias, look elsewhere.

item.title: The Right to Maim
item.description: In The Right to Maim Jasbir K. Puar brings her pathbreaking work on the liberal state, sexuality, and biopolitics to bear on our understanding of disability.

item.title: Wanted, A Gentleman
item.description: She had me at “gothic novelist” and “lonely hearts columnist.” This is wonderful. I love it when Charles just unleashes her id.

item.title: William Blake: The Complete Illuminated Books
item.description: Reading Blake, I always get the sense he’s working in a fever, trying to translate an ecstatic vision for us mortals.

item.title: Unfit to Print
item.description: Print shop feels! Plus the Victorian porn trade! And yes to showing this side of British colonialism, even if that could stand to be fleshed out a bit.

item.title: The Duchess War
item.description: Finally I didn’t bounce off a Courtney Milan! Granted, the Norfolk Southern disaster had me in the mood to read about labor organizing, and that part worked for me better than the romance.

item.title: Freak Pleasures
item.description: Now this is protest art. Specifically, the protest of SESTA/FOSTA and the censorship it entails, not to mention the way it endangers those it purports to protect.

item.title: Mutual Aid
item.description: In an explicit riposte to social Darwinists, Kropotkin argues against the theories that emphasize competition and survival of the fittest, and against the romantic depictions by writers such as Jean-Jacques Rousseau, who thought that cooperation was motivated by universal love.

item.title: Origin Story
item.description: If I had to comp this title, it’s like when I discovered Matt Dean, a talented writer self-publishing better litfic than 80% of the market, yet in a way that would earn rejections from most if not all of the big 5 and their imprints, as it’s not easily marketable as one thing or another.

item.title: The Chosen and the Beautiful
item.description: As someone who has long loved [[authors/f scott fitzgerald|F. Scott Fitzgerald]]’s writing, despite his depressing and often problematic deal, this [[books/the great gatsby|Gatsby]] retelling vis-à-vis a Vietnamese Jordan Baker is exquisite.

item.title: The Lathe Of Heaven
item.description: I can’t remember the last time I read a book with a truly passive protagonist, where his qualities are not his weakness, but his strength.

item.title: The Saint of Bright Doors
item.description: Gobsmacked at how good this is, without even the caveat of “for a first novel.” Fetter, the feral only child of a messiah, trained by his mother as assassin, destined to commit matricide and fratricide, navigates a dystopian Sri Lanka far too recognizable in the present.
